Private measures, random walks, and synthetic data

March Boedihardjo Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine marchb@uci.edu ,Â  Thomas Strohmer Department of Mathematics, University of California, Davis and Center of Data Science and Artificial Intelligence Research, UC Davis strohmer@math.ucdavis.edu Â andÂ  Roman Vershynin Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine rvershyn@uci.edu
Abstract.

Differential privacy is a mathematical concept that provides an information-theoretic se curity guarantee. While differential privacy has emerged as a de facto standard for guaranteeing privacy in data sharing, the known mechanisms to achieve it come with some serious limitations. Utility guarantees are usually provided only for a fixed, a priori specified set of queries. Moreover, there are no utility guarantees for more complexâ€”but very commonâ€”machine learning tasks such as clustering or classification. In this paper we overcome some of these limitations. Working with metric privacy, a powerful generalization of differential privacy, we develop a polynomial-time algorithm that creates a private measure from a data set. This private measure allows us to efficiently construct private synthetic data that are accurate for a wide range of statistical analysis tools. Moreover, we prove an asymptotically sharp min-max result for private measures and synthetic data for general compact metric spaces. A key ingredient in our construction is a new superregular random walk, whose joint distribution of steps is as regular as that of independent random variables, yet which deviates from the origin logarithmically slowly.

1. Introduction

1.1. Motivation

The right to privacy is enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human RightsÂ [7]. However, as artificial intelligence is more and more permeating our daily lives, data sharing is increasingly locking horns with data privacy concerns. Differential privacy (DP), a probabilistic mechanism that provides an information-theoretic privacy guarantee, has emerged as a de facto standard for implementing privacy in data sharingÂ [23]. For instance, DP has been adopted by several tech companiesÂ [21] and will also be used in connection with the release of the Census 2020 dataÂ [3, 2].

Yet, current embodiments of DP come with some serious limitationsÂ [18, 26, 52]:

  1. (i)

    Utility guarantees are usually provided only for a fixed set of queries. This means that either DP has to be used in an interactive scenario or the queries have to specified in advance.

  2. (ii)

    There are no utility guarantees for more complexâ€”but very commonâ€”machine learning tasks such as clustering or classification.

  3. (iii)

    DP can suffer from a poor privacy-utility tradeoff, leading to either insufficient privacy protection or to data sets of rather low utility, thereby making DP of limited use in many applicationsÂ [18].

Another approach to enable privacy in data sharing is based on the concept of synthetic dataÂ [9]. The goal of synthetic data is to create a dataset that maintains the statistical properties of the original data while not exposing sensitive information. The combination of differential privacy with synthetic data has been suggested as a best-of-both-world solutionsÂ [24, 9, 31, 35, 13]. While combining DP with synthetic data can indeed provide more flexibility and thereby partially address some of the issues inÂ (i), in and of itself it is not a panacea for the aforementioned problems.

One possibility to construct differentially private synthetic datasets that are not tailored to a priori specified queries is to simply add independent Laplacian noise to each data point. However, the amount noise that has to be added to achieve sufficient DP is too large with respect to maintaining satisfactory utility even for basic counting queriesÂ [53], not to mention more sophisticated machine learning tasks.

This raises the fundamental question whether it is even possible to construct in a numerically efficient manner differentially private synthetic data that come with rigorous utility guarantees for a wide range of (possibly complex) queries, while achieving a favorable privacy-utility tradeoff? In this paper we will answer this question to the affirmative.

1.2. A private measure

A main objective of this paper is to construct a private measure on a given metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho). Namely, we design an algorithm that transforms a probability measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu on Tğ‘‡T into another probability measure Î½ğœˆ\nu on Tğ‘‡T, and such that this transformation is both private and accurate.

For clarity, let us first consider the special case of empirical measures, where our goal can be understood as creating differentially private synthetic data. Specifically, we are looking for a computationally tractable algorithm that transforms true input data X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âˆˆTnğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} into synthetic output data Y=(Y1,â€¦,Ym)âˆˆTmğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘šY=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in T^{m} for some mğ‘šm, and which is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private (see DefinitionÂ 2.1) and such that the empirical measures

Î¼X=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ´XiandÎ¼Y=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mÎ´Yiformulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–andsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘Œ1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\mu_{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}}\quad\text{and}\quad\mu_{Y}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}}

are close to each other in the Wasserstein 1-metric (recalled in SectionÂ 2.2.2):

ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î¼X,Î¼Y)â‰¤Î³,ğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Œğ›¾\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{X},\mu_{Y}\right)\leq\gamma, (1.1)

where Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 is as small as possible.

The main result of this paper is a computationally effective private algorithm whose accuracy Î³ğ›¾\gamma that is expressed in terms of the multiscale geometry of the metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho). A consequence of this result, TheoremÂ 9.6, states that if the metric space has Minkowski dimension dâ‰¥1ğ‘‘1d\geq 1, then, ignoring the dependence on Îµğœ€\varepsilon and lower-order terms in the exponent, we have

ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î¼X,Î¼Y)âˆ¼nâˆ’1/dsimilar-toğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘›1ğ‘‘\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{X},\mu_{Y}\right)\sim n^{-1/d} (1.2)

The dependence on nğ‘›n is optimal and quite intuitive. Indeed, if the true data Xğ‘‹X consists of nğ‘›n i.i.d. random points chosen uniformly from the unit cube T=[0,1]dğ‘‡superscript01ğ‘‘T=[0,1]^{d}, then the average spacing between these points is of the order nâˆ’1/dsuperscriptğ‘›1ğ‘‘n^{-1/d}. So our result shows that privacy can be achieved by a microscopic perturbation, one whose magnitude is roughly the same as the average spacing between the points.

Our more general result, TheoremÂ 7.2, holds for arbitrary compact metric spaces (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) and, more importantly, for general input measures (not just empirical ones). To be able to work in such generality, we employ the notion of metric privacy which reduces to differential privacy when we specialize to empirical measures (SectionÂ 2.1).

1.3. Uniform accuracy over Lipschitz statistics

The choice of the Wasserstein 1-metric to quantify accuracy ensures that all Lipschitz statistics are preserved uniformly. Indeed, by Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality theorem, (1.1) yields

ğ”¼â€‹supf|1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfâ€‹(Xi)âˆ’1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mfâ€‹(Yi)|â‰¤Î³ğ”¼subscriptsupremumğ‘“1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šğ‘“subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ›¾\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\sup_{f}\Big{|}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(X_{i})-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}f(Y_{i})\Big{|}\leq\gamma (1.3)

where the supremum is over all 111-Lipschitz functions f:Tâ†’â„:ğ‘“ğ‘‡â†’â„f\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}T\to\mathbb{R}.

Standard private synthetic data generation methods that come with rigorous accuracy guarantees do so with respect to a predefined set of linear queries, such as low-dimensional marginals, see e.g.Â [8, 44, 22, 13]. While this may suffice in some cases, there is no assurance that the synthetic data behave in the same way as the original data under more complex, but frequently employed, machine learning techniques. For instance, if we want to apply a clustering method to the synthetic data, we cannot be sure that the results we get are close to those for the true data. This can drastically limit effective and reliable analysis of synthetic data.

In contrast, since the synthetic data constructed via our proposed method satisfy a uniform boundÂ (1.3), this provides data analysts with a vastly increased toolbox of machine learning methods for which one can expect outcomes that are similar for the original data and the synthetic data.

As concrete examples let us look at two of the most common tasks in machine learning, namely clustering and classification. While not every clustering method will satisfy a Lipschitz property, there do exist Lipschitz clustering functions that achieve state-of-the-art results, see e.g.Â [32, 55]. Similarly, there is distinct interest in Lipschitz function based classifiers, since they are more robust and less susceptible to adversarial attacks. This includes conventional classification methods such as support vector machinesÂ [51] as well as classifiers based on Lipschitz neural networksÂ [50, 10]. These are just a few examples of complex machine learning tools that can be reliably applied to the synthetic data constructed via our private measure algorithm. Moreover, since our results hold for general compact metric spaces, this paves the way for creating private synthetic data for a wide range of data types. We will present a detailed algorithmic and numerical investigation of the proposed method in a forthcoming paper.

1.4. A superregular random walk

The most popular way to achieve privacy is by adding random noise, typically either by adding an appropriate amount of Laplacian noise or Gaussian noise (these methods are aptly referred to as Laplacian mechanism and Gaussian mechanism, respectivelyÂ [23]). We, too, can try to make a probability measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu on Tğ‘‡T private by discretizing Tğ‘‡T (replacing it with a finite set of points) and then adding random noise to the weights of the points. Going this route, however, yields suboptimal results. For example, it is not difficult to check that if Tğ‘‡T is the interval [0,1]01[0,1], the accuracy of the Laplacian mechanism can not be better than nâˆ’1/2superscriptğ‘›12n^{-1/2}, which is suboptimal compared to optimal accuracy nâˆ’1superscriptğ‘›1n^{-1} in (1.2).

This loss of accuracy is caused by the accumulation of additive noise. Indeed, adding nğ‘›n independent random variables of unit variance produces noise of the order n1/2superscriptğ‘›12n^{1/2}. This prompts a basic probabilistic question: can we construct nğ‘›n random variables that are â€œcloseâ€ to being independent, but whose partial sums cancel more perfectly than those of independent random variables? We answer this question affirmatively in TheoremÂ 3.1, where we construct random variables Z1,â€¦,Znsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n} whose joint distribution is as regular as that of i.i.d.Â Laplacian random variables, yet whose partial sums grow logarithmically as opposed to n1/2superscriptğ‘›12n^{1/2}:

ğ”¼â¡max1â‰¤kâ‰¤nâ¡|Z1+â‹¯+Zk|=Oâ€‹(log2â¡n).ğ”¼subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\max_{1\leq k\leq n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{k}\right\rvert}=O(\log^{2}n).

One can think of this as a random walk that is locally similar to the one with i.i.d. steps, but globally is much more bounded. Our construction is a nontrivial modification of LÃ©vyâ€™s construction of Brownian motion. It may be interesting and useful beyond applications to privacy.

1.5. Comparison to existing work

The numerically efficient construction of accurate differentially private synthetic data is highly non-trivial. As case in point, Ullman and VadhanÂ [45] showed (under standard cryptographic assumptions) that in general it is NP-hard to make private synthetic Boolean data which approximately preserve all two-dimensional marginals. There exists a substantial body of work for generating privacy-preserving synthetic data, cf.Â e.g.Â [4, 15, 1, 17, 36], butâ€”unlike our workâ€”without providing any rigorous privacy or accuracy guarantees. Those papers on synthetic data that do provide rigorous guarantees are limited to accuracy bounds for a finite set of a priori specified queries, see for exampleÂ [8, 12, 44, 22, 13, 14], see also the tutorialÂ [46]. As discussed before, this may suffice for specific purposes, but in general severely limits the impact and usefulness of synthetic data. In contrast, the present work provides accuracy guarantees for a wide range of machine learning techniques. Furthermore, our our results hold for general compact metric spaces, as we establish metric privacy instead of just differential privacy.

A special example of the topic investigated in this paper is the publication of differentially private histograms, which is a well studied problem in the privacy literature, see e.g.Â [27, 40, 37, 54, 53, 38, 56, 2] and Chapter 4 inÂ [34]. In the specific context of histograms, the Haar function based approach to construct a superregular random walk proposed in our paper is related to the wavelet-based methodÂ [53] and to other hierarchical histogram partitioning methodsÂ [27, 40, 56]. Like our approach, [27, 53] obtain consistency of counting queries across the hierarchical levels, owing to the specific way that noise is added. Also, the accuracy bounds obtained inÂ [27, 53] are similar to ours, as they are also polylogarithmic (although we are able to obtain a smaller exponent). There are, however, several key differences. While our approach gives a convenient way to generate accurate and differentially private synthetic data Yğ‘ŒY from true data Xğ‘‹X, the methods of the aforementioned papers are not suited to create synthetic data. Instead, these methods release answers to queries. Moreover, accuracy is proven for just a single given range query and not simultaneously for all queries like we do. This limitation makes it impossible to create accurate synthetic data with the algorithms inÂ [27, 53]. Moreover, unlike the aforementioned papers, our work allows the data to be quite general, since we prove metric privacy and not just differential privacy. Furthermore, our results apply to multi-dimensional data, and are not limited to the one-dimensional setting.

There exist several papers on the private estimation of density and other statistical quantitiesÂ [28, 19], and sampling from distributions in a private manner is the topic ofÂ [41]. While definitely interesting, that line of work is not concerned with synthetic data, and thus there is little overlap with this work.

1.6. The architecture of the paper

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We introduce some background material and notation in SectionÂ 2, such as the concept of metric privacy which generalizes differential privacy. In SectionÂ 3 we construct a superregular random walk (TheoremÂ 3.1). We analyze metric privacy in more detail in SectionÂ 4, where we also provide a link from the general private measure problem to private synthetic data (LemmaÂ 4.1). In SectionÂ 5 we use the superregular random walk to construct a private measure on the interval [0,1]01[0,1] (TheoremÂ 5.4). In SectionÂ 6 we use a link between the Traveling Salesman Problem and minimum spanning trees to devise a folding technique, which we apply in SectionÂ 7 to â€œfoldâ€ the interval into a space-filling curve to construct a private measure on a general metric space (TheoremÂ 7.2). Postprocessing the private measure with quantization and splitting, we then generate private synthetic data in a general metric space (CorollaryÂ 7.4). In SectionÂ 8 we turn to lower bounds for private measures (TheoremÂ 8.5) and synthetic data (TheoremÂ 8.6) on a general metric space. We do this by employing a technique of Hardt and Talwar, which we present in a PropositionÂ 8.1 that identifies general limitations for synthetic data. In SectionÂ 9 we illustrate our general results on a specific example of a metric space: the Boolean cube [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d}. We construct a private measure (CorollaryÂ 9.1) and private synthetic data (CorollaryÂ 9.2) on the cube, and show near optimality of these results in CorollaryÂ 9.3 and CorollaryÂ 9.4, respectively. Results similar to the ones for the dğ‘‘d-dimensional cube hold for arbitrary metric space of Minkowski dimension dğ‘‘d. For any such space, we prove an asymptotically sharp min-max results for private measures (TheoremÂ 9.5) and synthetic data (TheoremÂ 9.5).

2. Background and Notation

The motivation behind the concept of differential privacy is the desire to protect an individualâ€™s data, while publishing aggregate information about the databaseÂ [23]. Adding or removing the data of one individual should have a negligible effect on the query outcome, as formalized in the following definition.

Definition 2.1 (Differential PrivacyÂ [23]).

A randomized algorithm â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} gives Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differential privacy if for any input databases Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} differing on at most one element, and any measurable subset SâŠ†rangeâ¡(â„³)ğ‘†rangeâ„³S\subseteq\operatorname{range}({\mathcal{M}}), we have

â„™â€‹{â„³â€‹(D)âˆˆSâ€‹}â„™â€‹{â„³â€‹(Dâ€²)âˆˆSâ€‹}â‰¤expâ¡(Îµ),â„™â„³ğ·ğ‘†â„™â„³superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘†ğœ€\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{{\mathcal{M}}(D)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{{\mathcal{M}}(D^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq\exp(\varepsilon),

where the probability is with respect to the randomness of â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}.

2.1. Defining metric privacy

While differential privacy is a concept of the discrete world (where datasets can differ in a single element), it is often desirable to have more freedom in the choice of input data. The following general notion (which seems to be known under slightly different, and somewhat less general, versions, see e.g.Â [5] and the references therein) extends the classical concept of differential privacy.

Definition 2.2 (Metric privacy).

Let (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) be a compact metric space and Eğ¸E be a measurable space. A randomized algorithm ğ’œ:Tâ†’E:ğ’œğ‘‡â†’ğ¸\mathcal{A}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}T\to E is called Î±ğ›¼\alpha-metrically private if, for any inputs x,xâ€²âˆˆTğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘‡x,x^{\prime}\in T and any measurable subset SâŠ‚Eğ‘†ğ¸S\subset E, we have

â„™â€‹{ğ’œâ€‹(x)âˆˆSâ€‹}â„™â€‹{ğ’œâ€‹(xâ€²)âˆˆSâ€‹}â‰¤expâ¡(Î±â€‹Ïâ€‹(x,xâ€²)).â„™ğ’œğ‘¥ğ‘†â„™ğ’œsuperscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘†ğ›¼ğœŒğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(x)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(x^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq\exp\left(\alpha\,\rho(x,x^{\prime})\right). (2.1)

To see how this metric privacy encompasses differential privacy, consider a product space T=ğ’³nğ‘‡superscriptğ’³ğ‘›T=\mathcal{X}^{n} and equip it with the Hamming distance

The Î±ğ›¼\alpha-differentially privacy of an algorithm ğ’œ:ğ’³nâ†’E:ğ’œsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›â†’ğ¸\mathcal{A}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathcal{X}^{n}\to E can be expressed as

Note that (2.3) is equivalent to (2.1) for Ï=ÏHğœŒsubscriptğœŒğ»\rho=\rho_{H}. Obviously, (2.1) implies (2.3). Lemma 2.3 (MP vs.Â DP).

Let ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} be an arbitrary set. Then an algorithm ğ’œ:ğ’³nâ†’E:ğ’œsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›â†’ğ¸\mathcal{A}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathcal{X}^{n}\to E is Î±ğ›¼\alpha-differentially private if an only if ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is Î±ğ›¼\alpha-metrically private with respect to the Hamming distance (2.2) on ğ’³nsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{X}^{n}.

Unlike differential privacy, metric privacy goes beyond product spaces, and thus allows the data to be quite general. In this paper, for example, the input data are probability measures. Moreover, metric privacy does away with the assumption that the data sets D,Dâ€²ğ·superscriptğ·â€²D,D^{\prime} be different in a single element. This assumption is sometimes too restrictive: general measures, for example, do not break down into natural single elements.

This paper will use three classical notions of distance between measures.

Vallenderâ€™s identity (2.7) can be used to define Wasserstein distance for signed measures on â„â„\mathbb{R}. Moreover, for signed measures on [0,1]01[0,1], the Wasserstein distance defined this way is always finite, and it defines a pseudometric.

3. A superregular random walk

The classical random walk with independent steps of unit variance is not bounded: it deviates from the origin at the expected rate âˆ¼n1/2similar-toabsentsuperscriptğ‘›12\sim n^{1/2}. Surprisingly, there exists a random walk whose joint distribution of steps is as regular as that of independent Laplacians, yet that deviates from the origin logarithmically slowly.

Theorem 3.1 (A superregular random walk).

For every nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}, there exists a probability density of the form fâ€‹(z)=1Î²â€‹eâˆ’Vâ€‹(z)ğ‘“ğ‘§1ğ›½superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‰ğ‘§f(z)=\frac{1}{\beta}e^{-V(z)} on â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n} that satisfies the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Regularity): the potential Vğ‘‰V is 111-Lipschitz in the â„“1superscriptâ„“1\ell^{1} norm, i.e.

  2. (ii)

    (Boundedness): a random vector Z=(Z1,â€¦,Zn)ğ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›Z=(Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}) distributed according to the density fğ‘“f satisfies

    ğ”¼â¡max1â‰¤kâ‰¤nâ¡|Z1+â‹¯+Zk|â‰¤Câ€‹log2â¡n,ğ”¼subscript1ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ¶superscript2ğ‘›\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\max_{1\leq k\leq n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{k}\right\rvert}\leq C\log^{2}n, (3.2)

3.1. Heuristics

The first candidate for the random walk could be a discretization of the standard Brownian motion on the interval [0,1]01[0,1]. The reflection principle yields the boundedness property in the theorem, even without any logarithmic loss. However, the regularity property fails miserably.

To achieve regularity, we would like to grant Brownian motion more freedom. This will be done by modifying Levyâ€™s construction of the Brownian motion. In this construction, the path of a Brownian motion on an interval [0,n]0ğ‘›[0,n] is defined as a random series with respect to the Schauder basis of the space of continuous functions, see alsoÂ [11, Section IX.1].

3.5. Optimality

The reader might wonder if the logarithmic factors are necessary in TheoremÂ 3.1. While we do not know if this is the case for the bound (3.3), the logarithmic factor can not be completely removed from the uniform bound (3.2):

3.6. Beyond the â„“1superscriptâ„“1\ell^{1} norm?

One may wonder why specifically the â„“1superscriptâ„“1\ell^{1} norm appears in the regularity property of TheoremÂ 3.1. As we will see shortly, the regularity with respect to the â„“1superscriptâ„“1\ell^{1} norm is exactly what is needed in our applications to privacy. However, it might be interesting to see if there are natural extensions of TheoremÂ 3.1 for general â„“psuperscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell^{p} norms. The lemma below rules out one such avenue, showing that if a potential Vğ‘‰V is Lipschitz with respect to the â„“psuperscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell^{p} norm for some p>1ğ‘1p>1, the corresponding random walk deviates at least polynomially fast (as opposed to logarithmically fast).

4. Metric privacy

4.1. Private measures

The superregular random walk we just constructed will become the main tool in solving the following private measure problem. We are looking for a private and accurate algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} that transforms a probability measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu on a metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) into another finitely-supported probability measure ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼)ğ’œğœ‡\mathcal{A}(\mu) on (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho).

We need to specify what we mean by privacy and accuracy here. Metric privacy offers a natural framework for our problem. Namely, we consider DefinitionÂ 2.2 for the space (â„³â€‹(T),TV)â„³ğ‘‡TV(\mathcal{M}(T),\mathrm{TV}) of all probability measures on Tğ‘‡T equipped with the TV metric (recalled in SectionÂ 2.2.1). Thus, for any pair of input measures Î¼ğœ‡\mu and Î¼â€²superscriptğœ‡â€²\mu^{\prime} on Tğ‘‡T that are close in the TV metric, we would like the distributions of the (random) output measures ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼)ğ’œğœ‡\mathcal{A}(\mu) and ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼â€²)ğ’œsuperscriptğœ‡â€²\mathcal{A}(\mu^{\prime}) to be close:

â„™â€‹{ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼)âˆˆSâ€‹}â„™â€‹{ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼â€²)âˆˆSâ€‹}â‰¤expâ¡(Î±â€‹âˆ¥Î¼âˆ’Î¼â€²âˆ¥TV).â„™ğ’œğœ‡ğ‘†â„™ğ’œsuperscriptğœ‡â€²ğ‘†ğ›¼subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‡superscriptğœ‡â€²TV\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq\exp\left(\alpha\mathinner{\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\right). (4.1)

The accuracy will be measured via the Wasserstein distance (recalled in SectionÂ 2.2.2). We hope to make W1â€‹(ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼),Î¼)subscriptğ‘Š1ğ’œğœ‡ğœ‡W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu) as small as possible. The reason for choosing W1subscriptğ‘Š1W_{1} as distance is that it allows us to derive accuracy guarantees for general Lipschitz statistics, as outlined below.

4.2. Synthetic data

The private measure problem has an immediate application for differentially private synthetic data. Let (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. We hope to find an algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} that transforms the true data X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âˆˆTnğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} into synthetic data Y=(Y1,â€¦,Ym)âˆˆTmğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘šY=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in T^{m} for some mğ‘šm such that the empirical measures

Î¼X=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ´XiandÎ¼Y=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mÎ´Yiformulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–andsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘Œ1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\mu_{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}}\quad\text{and}\quad\mu_{Y}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}}

are close in the Wasserstein distance, i.e. we hope to make W1â€‹(Î¼X,Î¼Y)subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ‘ŒW_{1}(\mu_{X},\mu_{Y}) small. This would imply that synthetic data accurately preserves all Lipschitz statistics, i.e.

1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfâ€‹(Xi)â‰ˆ1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mfâ€‹(Yi)1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šğ‘“subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(X_{i})\approx\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}f(Y_{i})

for any Lipschitz function f:Tâ†’â„:ğ‘“ğ‘‡â†’â„f\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}T\to\mathbb{R}.

This goal can be immediately achieved if we solve a version of the private measure problem, described in SectionÂ 4.1, with the additional requirement that ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼)ğ’œğœ‡\mathcal{A}(\mu) be an empirical measure. Indeed, define the algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} by feeding the empirical measure Î¼Xsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹\mu_{X} into ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, i.e. set â„¬â€‹(X)=ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼X)â„¬ğ‘‹ğ’œsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹\mathcal{B}(X)=\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X}). The accuracy follows, and the differential privacy of â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} can be seen as follows.

For any pair X,Xâ€²ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹â€²X,X^{\prime} of input data that differ in a single element, the corresponding empirical measures differ by at most 1/n1ğ‘›1/n with respect to the TV distance, i.e.

âˆ¥Î¼Xâˆ’Î¼Xâ€²âˆ¥TVâ‰¤1n.subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡superscriptğ‘‹â€²TV1ğ‘›\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{X}-\mu_{X^{\prime}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\frac{1}{n}.

Then, for any subset Sğ‘†S in the output space, we can use (4.1) to get

â„™â€‹{â„¬â€‹(X)âˆˆSâ€‹}â„™â€‹{â„¬â€‹(Xâ€²)âˆˆSâ€‹}=â„™â€‹{ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼X)âˆˆSâ€‹}â„™â€‹{ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼Xâ€²)âˆˆSâ€‹}â‰¤expâ¡(Î±â€‹âˆ¥Î¼âˆ’Î¼â€²âˆ¥TV)â‰¤expâ¡(Î±/n).â„™â„¬ğ‘‹ğ‘†â„™â„¬superscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘†â„™ğ’œsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹ğ‘†â„™ğ’œsubscriptğœ‡superscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘†ğ›¼subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‡superscriptğœ‡â€²TVğ›¼ğ‘›\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{B}(X)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{B}(X^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}=\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X^{\prime}})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq\exp\left(\alpha\,\mathinner{\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\right)\leq\exp(\alpha/n).

Thus, if Î±=Îµâ€‹nğ›¼ğœ€ğ‘›\alpha=\varepsilon n, the algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private. Let us record this observation formally.

Lemma 4.1 (Private measure yields private synthetic data).

Let (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Let ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} be an algorithm that inputs a probability measure on Tğ‘‡T, and outputs something. Define the algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} that takes data X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âˆˆTnğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} as an input, creates the empirical measure Î¼Xsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹\mu_{X} and feeds it into the algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, i.e. set â„¬â€‹(X)=ğ’œâ€‹(Î¼X)â„¬ğ‘‹ğ’œsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹\mathcal{B}(X)=\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X}). If ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is Î±ğ›¼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric and Î±=Îµâ€‹nğ›¼ğœ€ğ‘›\alpha=\varepsilon n, then â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private.

Thus, our main focus from now on will be on solving the private measure problem; private synthetic data will follows as a consequence.

5.2. Extending the input space to the interval

Next, we would like to extend our framework to a continuous setting, and allow measures to be supported by the entire interval [0,1]01[0,1]. We can do this by quantization.

5.2.2. A private measure on the interval

6. The Traveling Salesman Problem

In order to extend the construction of the private measure on the interval [0,1]01[0,1] to a general metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho), a natural approach would be to map the interval [0,1]01[0,1] onto some space-filling curve of Tğ‘‡T. Since a space filling curves usually are infinitely long, we should do this on the discrete level, for some Î´ğ›¿\delta-net of Tğ‘‡T rather than Tğ‘‡T itself. In this section, we will bound length of such discrete space-filling curve in terms of the metric geometry of Tğ‘‡T. In the next section, we will see how this bound determines the accuracy of a private measure in Tğ‘‡T.

A natural framework for this step is related to Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP), which is a central problem in optimization and computer science, and whose history goes back to at least 1832 [6].

Let G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) be an undirected weighted connected graph. We occasionally refer to the weights of the edges as lengths. A tour of GğºG is a connected walk on the edges that visits every vertex at least once, and returns to the starting vertex. The TSP is the problem of finding a tour of GğºG with the shortest length. Let us denote this length by TSPâ¡(G)TSPğº\operatorname{TSP}(G).

Although it is NP-hard to compute TSP(G), or even to approximate it within a factor of 123/122123122123/122 [30], an algorithm of Christofides and Serdyukov [16, 43] from 1976 gives a 3/2323/2-approximation for TSP, and it was shown recently that the factor 3/2323/2 can be further improved [29].

6.1. TSP in terms of the minimum spanning tree

Within a factor of 222, the traveling salesman problem is equivalent to another key problem, namely the problem of finding the minimum spanning tree (MST) of GğºG. A spanning tree of GğºG is a subgraph that is a tree and which includes all vertices of GğºG. It always exists and can be found in polynomial timeÂ [33, 39]. A spanning tree of GğºG with the smallest length is called the minimum spanning tree of GğºG; we denote its length by MSTâ¡(G)MSTğº\operatorname{MST}(G). The following equivalence is a folklore.

Lemma 6.1.

Any undirected weighted connected graph GğºG satisfies

MSTâ¡(G)â‰¤TSPâ¡(G)â‰¤2â€‹MSTâ¡(G).MSTğºTSPğº2MSTğº\operatorname{MST}(G)\leq\operatorname{TSP}(G)\leq 2\operatorname{MST}(G).
Proof.

For the lower bound, it is enough to find a spanning tree of GğºG of length bounded by TSPâ¡(G)TSPğº\operatorname{TSP}(G). Consider the minimal tour of GğºG of length TSPâ¡(G)TSPğº\operatorname{TSP}(G) as a subgraph of GğºG. Let Tğ‘‡T be a spanning tree of the tour. Since the tour contains all vertices of GğºG, so does Tğ‘‡T, and thus Tğ‘‡T is a spanning tree of GğºG. Since Tğ‘‡T is obtained by removing some edges of the tour, the length of Tğ‘‡T is bounded by of the tour, which is TSPâ¡(G)TSPğº\operatorname{TSP}(G). The lower bound is proved.

For the upper bound, note that dropping any edges of GğºG can only increase the value of TSP. Thus TSP of GğºG is bounded by the TSP of its spanning tree Tğ‘‡T. Moreover, TSP of any tree Tğ‘‡T equals twice the sum of lengths of the edges of Tğ‘‡T. This can be seen by considering the depth-first search tour of Tğ‘‡T, which starts at the root and explores as deep as possible along each branch before backtracking, see FigureÂ 3. âˆ

6.2. Metric TSP

Let (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) be a finite metric space. We can consider Tğ‘‡T as a complete weighted graph, whose weights of edges are defined as the distances between the points. The TSP for (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) is known as metric TSP.

Although a tour can visit the same vertex of Tğ‘‡T multiple times, this can be prevented by skipping the vertices previously visited. The triangle inequality shows that skipping can only decrease the length of the tour. Therefore, the shortest tour in a complete graph is always a Hamiltonian cycle, a walk that visits all vertices of Tğ‘‡T exactly once before returning to the starting vertex. Let us record this observation:

Lemma 6.2.

The TSP of a finite metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) equals the smallest length of a Hamiltonian cycle of Tğ‘‡T.

6.3. A geometric bound on TSP

We would like to compute TSPâ¡(T)TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{TSP}(T) in terms of the geometry of the metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho). Here we will prove an upper bound on TSPâ¡(T)TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{TSP}(T) in terms of the covering numbers. Recall that the covering number Nâ€‹(T,Ï,Îµ)ğ‘ğ‘‡ğœŒğœ€N(T,\rho,\varepsilon) is defined as the smallest cardinality of an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-net of Tğ‘‡T, or equivalently the smallest number of closed balls with centers in Tğ‘‡T and radii Îµğœ€\varepsilon whose union covers Tğ‘‡T, see [48, SectionÂ 4.2].

In other words, Fğ¹F is 111-Lipschitz. The proof is complete. âˆ

7. A private measure on a metric space

We are ready to construct a private measure on an arbitrary compact metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho). We do this as follows: (a) discretize Tğ‘‡T replacing it with a finite Î´ğ›¿\delta-net; (b) fold an interval of length TSPâ¡(T)TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{TSP}(T) onto Tğ‘‡T using PropositionÂ 6.5; and (c) using this folding, pushforward onto Tğ‘‡T the private measure on the interval constructed in SectionÂ 5. The accuracy of the resulting private measure on Tğ‘‡T is determined by the length of the interval TSPâ¡(T)TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{TSP}(T), which in turn can be expressed using the covering numbers of Tğ‘‡T (TheoremÂ 6.3).

7.1. Finite metric spaces

Let us start by extending PropositionÂ 5.2 from a finite subset on [0,1]01[0,1] to a finite subset of (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho).

Proposition 7.1 (Private measure on a finite metric space).

Let (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) be a finite metric space and let n=|T|ğ‘›ğ‘‡n=\mathinner{\!\left\lvert T\right\rvert}. Let Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. There exists a randomized algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} that takes a probability measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu on Tğ‘‡T as an input and returns a probability measure Î½ğœˆ\nu on Tğ‘‡T as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} is Î±ğ›¼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î½,Î¼)â‰¤Câ€‹log32â¡nÎ±â€‹TSPâ¡(T).ğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1ğœˆğœ‡ğ¶superscript32ğ‘›ğ›¼TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}\,\operatorname{TSP}(T).
Proof.

Applying Folding PropositionÂ 6.5, we obtain an nğ‘›n-element subset Î©âŠ‚[0,TSPâ¡(T)]Î©0TSPğ‘‡\Omega\subset[0,\operatorname{TSP}(T)] and a 111-Lipschitz bijection F:Î©â†’T:ğ¹Î©â†’ğ‘‡F\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\Omega\to T. Applying PropositionÂ 5.2 and rescaling by the factor TSPâ¡(T)TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{TSP}(T), we obtain an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-metrically private algorithm â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} that transforms a probability measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu on Î©Î©\Omega into a probability measure Î½ğœˆ\nu on Î©Î©\Omega, and whose accuracy is

ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î½,Î¼)â‰¤Câ€‹log32â¡nÎ±â€‹TSPâ¡(T).ğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1ğœˆğœ‡ğ¶superscript32ğ‘›ğ›¼TSPğ‘‡\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}\,\operatorname{TSP}(T). (7.1)

Define a new metric ÏÂ¯Â¯ğœŒ\bar{\rho} on Î©Î©\Omega by ÏÂ¯â€‹(x,y)=Ïâ€‹(Fâ€‹(x),Fâ€‹(y))Â¯ğœŒğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœŒğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¦\bar{\rho}(x,y)=\rho\left(F(x),F(y)\right). Therefore, the bound (7.1), which holds with respect to the usual metric |xâˆ’y|ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mathinner{\!\left\lvert x-y\right\rvert} on Î©Î©\Omega, automatically holds with respect to the smaller metric ÏÂ¯â€‹(x,y)Â¯ğœŒğ‘¥ğ‘¦\bar{\rho}(x,y).

It remains to note that (Î©,ÏÂ¯)Î©Â¯ğœŒ(\Omega,\bar{\rho}) is isometric to (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho). So the accuracy result (7.1), which as we saw holds in (Î©,ÏÂ¯)Î©Â¯ğœŒ(\Omega,\bar{\rho}), automatically transfers to (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) (by considering the pushforward measure). âˆ

Remark 7.5 (A computationally effective algorithm).

We will present a detailed discussion of the algorithmic aspects of the proposed synthetic data generation method in a forthcoming paper. Here, we only mention that our algorithm works in polynomial time444under the stipulation that an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-net (of polynomial cardinality) can be constructed in polynomial time with respect to the cardinality of the dataset. To be more precise, assuming that the input measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu is given by an oracle for any set Ağ´A, the oracle gives us Î¼â€‹(A)ğœ‡ğ´\mu(A) and we need a polynomial number of calls to such an oracle.

8. A lower bound

This section is devoted to impossibility results, which yield lower bounds on the accuracy of any private measure on a general metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho). While there may be a gap between our upper and lower bounds for general metric spaces, we will see in SectionÂ 9 that this gap vanishes asymptotically for spaces of Minkowski dimension dğ‘‘d.

The proof of the lower bound uses the geometric method pioneered by Hardt and Talwar [25]. A lower bound is more convenient to express in terms of packing rather than covering numbers. Recall that the packing number Npackâ€‹(T,Ï,Îµ)subscriptğ‘packğ‘‡ğœŒğœ€{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,\varepsilon) of a compact metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) is defined as the largest cardinality of an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-separated subset of Tğ‘‡T. The covering and packing numbers are equivalent up to a factor of 222:

Npackâ€‹(T,Ï,2â€‹Îµ)â‰¤Nâ€‹(T,Ï,Îµ)â‰¤Npackâ€‹(T,Ï,Îµ),subscriptğ‘packğ‘‡ğœŒ2ğœ€ğ‘ğ‘‡ğœŒğœ€subscriptğ‘packğ‘‡ğœŒğœ€{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,2\varepsilon)\leq N(T,\rho,\varepsilon)\leq{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,\varepsilon), (8.1)

see [48, LemmaÂ 4.2.8]. Thus, in all results of this section, packing numbers can be replaced by covering numbers at the cost of changing absolute constants.

8.3. Lower bounds for private measures and synthetic data

Now we are ready to prove the two main lower bounds on the accuracy for (a) metrically private measures and (b) differential private data.

Theorem 8.5 (Private measure: a lower bound).

Let (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Assume that for some t>0ğ‘¡0t>0 and Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1 we have

ğ”¼â¡W1â€‹(Î½,Î¼)>t/12.ğ”¼subscriptğ‘Š1ğœˆğœ‡ğ‘¡12\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)>t/12.
Proof.

9.2. Asymptotic result

The only property of the cube T=[0,1]dğ‘‡superscript01ğ‘‘T=[0,1]^{d} we used in the previous section is the behavior on its covering numbers,666The lower bound used packing numbers, but they are equivalent to covering numbers due to (8.1). namely that

Nâ€‹(T,Ï,x)â‰(1/x)âˆ’d,x>0.formulae-sequenceasymptotically-equalsğ‘ğ‘‡ğœŒğ‘¥superscript1ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¥0N(T,\rho,x)\asymp(1/x)^{-d},\quad x>0. (9.1)

Therefore, the same results on private measures and synthetic data hold for any compact metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) whose covering numbers behave this way. In particular, it follows that any probability measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu on Tğ‘‡T can be transformed into a Î±ğ›¼\alpha-metrically private measure Î½ğœˆ\nu on Tğ‘‡T, with accuracy

ğ”¼â¡Wâ€‹(Î½,Î¼)â‰(1/Î±)1/d.asymptotically-equalsğ”¼ğ‘Šğœˆğœ‡superscript1ğ›¼1ğ‘‘\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W(\nu,\mu)\asymp(1/\alpha)^{1/d}. (9.2)

(ignoring logarithmic factors), and this result is nearly sharp. Similarly, any true data XâˆˆTnğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›X\in T^{n} can be transformed into Îµğœ€\varepsilon-differentially private synthetic data YâˆˆTmğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘šY\in T^{m} for some mğ‘šm, with accuracy

ğ”¼â¡Wâ€‹(Î¼Y,Î¼X)â‰(1/n)1/d.asymptotically-equalsğ”¼ğ‘Šsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘Œsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘‹superscript1ğ‘›1ğ‘‘\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W(\mu_{Y},\mu_{X})\asymp(1/n)^{1/d}. (9.3)

(ignoring logarithmic factors and dependence on Îµğœ€\varepsilon), and this result is nearly sharp.

These intuitive observations can be formalized using the notion of Minkowski dimension. By definition, the metric space (T,Ï)ğ‘‡ğœŒ(T,\rho) has Minkowski dimension dğ‘‘d if

limxâ†’0logâ¡Nâ€‹(T,Ï,x)logâ¡(1/x)=d.subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥0ğ‘ğ‘‡ğœŒğ‘¥1ğ‘¥ğ‘‘\lim_{x\to 0}\frac{\log N(T,\rho,x)}{\log(1/x)}=d.

The following two asymptotic results combine upper and lower bounds, and essentially show that (9.2) and (9.3) hold in any space of dimension dğ‘‘d.
